title: david-mundell-defends-vote-upset-farmers
story: TWEEDDALE MP David Mundell has defended himself after rejecting a chance to protect farmers from low quality imports.Mr Mundell and Borders MP John Lamontwereamong the Westminster parliamentarians who voted against a bid to ban hormone-injected beef.Some farming figures criticised MPs for their actions, but Mr Mundell has insisted his Conservative Party colleagues want to support the agriculture industry.Mr Mundell said: "Ministers have pledged to keep our import standards, which include the ban on chlorine-washed chicken and hormone-injected beef.Devon MP Neil Parishrsquos suggested amendment to the Agriculture Bill was turned down in the House of Commons on May .If the amendment had been successful, in future the UK would only be able to accept other countriesrsquo food itemsthey had been produced to the equivalent welfare standards upheld in Britain.NFU Scotlandrsquos policy director Jonnie Hall said it was ldquodeeply disappointing that the amendment lost by  votes.Meanwhile, Borders farmer Alec Wilson said: ldquoI fear the worst every time Westminster has anything to do with agricultural policy.Mr Mundell, who represents Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale, told this newspaper that while he understood the intentions behind Mr Parishrsquos amendment, he feared the impact it would have on trade negotiations.However, the former Scottish Secretary believes Boris Johnsonrsquos government ldquoremains committed to protecting farmers and consumers.He said: ldquoNo UK import standards would be diminished as part of any future trade agreement."The government also stresses they will not undermine the UKs high domestic environmental protection, animal welfare and food safety standards by enshrining in any agreement that British farmers are always able to compete."

title: schoolboy-runs-50-miles-50-days-salvation-army
story: A BORDERS schoolboy has run  miles in  days to support homeless people.Robert Horton, nine, launched a fundraising challenge to help the Salvation Army after seeing a distressing news report.The St Ronans Primary School pupil has now completed his task ndash much to his fathers delight.Stephen Horton, of Innerleithen, said: "He hasnrsquot grumbled about it once ndash hersquos even been out in the wind and rain."Robert, a member of the Leithenburn Runners, came up with his project after learning about the struggle faced by homeless people.He said: "I felt sad that they had no food and had nowhere to stay and thought someone should help."Originally, Robert had planned to run every day for a month, but he decided to add an extra  days.During the challenge, he told this newspaper he was "tired", but added: "I will finish."Robert has raised more than pound so far, smashing his original target of pound.Mr Horton said he was "very proud" of his sons athletic achievement.The advanced nurse practitioner said: "I was sure that, physically, he was able."Hes in Leithenburn Runners and is doing pretty well."He runs everywhere, even bits of Lee Pen."But to stick at it for  days is excellent."Mr Horton and his we Lynsey were both able to join Robert on some of his runs.Robert has not been to school since March  due to the coronavirus outbreak.He said: "I miss all my friends from school and some of the clubs."Mr Horton added: "As a family its been challenging."As Im still at work, Lynsey has had to do the home-schooling."I think now we are starting to get used to the routine a bit better."But its fair to say the children miss seeing their friends ndash but WhatsApp and FaceTime have helped that in some way."Its hard for everyone not seeing their family."To donate to Roberts fundraiser, you can visit this website.

title: glasgow-parents-need-know-school-reopen-date-confirmed
story: NICOLA Sturgeonyesterdayconfirmedpupils from all of Scotlands schools are set toto classrooms inAugust.The First Minister revealed this will be a "blended" approach, far from normality for our nations youngsters, as part of a four-phase plan to ease the lockdown.But even this is reliant on two key factors -the scientic andmedical advice confirms it can be done in a way that will not disrupt efforts to control the virus andthere is sufficient PPE and other hygiene measures in place.Following Ms Sturgeons announcement in parliament, the Scottish Government published its strategic framework for the re-opening of schools.Here, well detailwhat parents need to know ahead of their childsto the classroom.When will schools re-open Schools in Scotland are set to re-open on August .This is earlier than planned for some schools - but the universal approach is being advised by the Scottish Government.Teachers are set toto the classroom by June to plan and prepare for the new blended model of learning.Some pupils set to start P or S may also receive some in-school experience in late June, to help ensure they are supported to make the next steps in their education.Critical childcare will continue until August to ensure the ongoing provision for key worker and vulnerable children.How will the blended model work Under this approach, children will have a mixture of in-school and in-home learning.According to the framework, this is reliant on consistent and easy-to-use in-home materials which are "intended to support and complement, but not replicate" in-school learning.To help disadvantaged pupils, a further poundm was announced to provide laptops and other technology for the home learning.However the document notes: "No matter how well planned in-home learning is, it is not the same as having effective learning and teaching within the school environment, led by teachers."The blended model will be kept under constant review.How will pupils social distance For the first phase of re-opening, schools are being asked to assess the maximum numbers they can accommodate, with guidance including:Pupils being taught in smaller groupsThese groups will not be mixed, where practicableSeating positions will be re-organised to allow for m gaps between pupilsOutdoor space will be used moreThere will be staggered arrival and departure times, so parents will avoid congregating in playground areasBreaks will be staggered by class to avoid contact from dferent classesTeachers, rather than pupils, will move around classrooms where possibleThere will be enhanced hygiene practices across all schools, including additional cleaning,params: .pushExpanding the learning estateLocal authorities are being advised to look for ways they can maximise the capacity for pupils to benefit from in-school learning as much as possible.One such way they are doing this is through expanding the learning estate.This would mean seeingclassrooms could be made fromoutdoor space,libraries, community halls, leisure centres and conference centres.It might also include taking short-term leases of vacant business accommodation.Who will be prioritised for in-school learning As set out above, there is likely going to be a finite number of daily places for in-school learning.As a result, to support NHS capacity and other essential work, a priority will be given to the children of keyworkers - but this is only in circumstances where absolutely necessary with no other option for childcare within that household.The remaining allocation is to be distributed across all year groups to ensure every pupils benefits from in-school learning where possible, according to the framework.Local authorities are being advices to use their knowledge of local circumstances to prioritise any groups where need is greatest.Speaking in the Scottish Parliament on Thursday, the First Minister said: ldquoThese arrangements will not represent a completeto normality by August.ldquoBut we judge them to be the most sensible approach we can plan for at this stage.Later in the session, the First Minister said the Scottish Government wants to ensure pupils will be back at school ldquoin a way that allows them to be children.She added: ldquoNone of us relish the prospect of seeing kids, particularly young kids, socially distancing or be as aware of these risks as we will undoubtedly have to require them to be.ldquoTrying to get, for children in particular, as much normality as possible in the school environment is really important.ldquoWe shouldnrsquot underestimate the challenges of that but it is absolutely central to all of this careful planning that is underway.

title: can-pubs-reopen-glasgow-plan-ease-lockdown-revealed
story: THE Scottish Government yesterday set out a route-map showing plans to ease out of the coronavirus lockdown.The four-phase plan will begin as of next week, with a number of measures being relaxed on May .More outdoor activity including sportsmeeting other households and the re-opening of recycling centres are among those being re-introduced at what is being described as Phase .But these areentirely dependent on dramatically reducing coronavirusin the country and successfully implementing a ldquoTest and Protect strategy.But what about pubs For those of us hankering for a leisurely drink in our local, the subject of ing to Scotlands pubs has been addressed in the route map.Current lockdown restrictions mean pubs and restaurants have been forced to close.The measures introduced yesterday also reveal that pubs will be forced to remain closed during Phase  - meaning they will notbe open on May .What about beer gardens Much of the new data being discussed by Scottish Government officials is around the potential for greater outdoor activity - which can be seen around plans for easing exercise restrictions.As such, the re-opening of pubs will begin with beer gardens.Under the plans, pubs and restaurants with outdoor spaces can reopen in Phase  - the exact date of which is not yet clear.This will be done provided social distancing is met and there are increased hygiene measures.So, when can I get inside a pub The route-map suggests that pubs can open their indoor spaces from Phase  in the four-phased plan.This will again only be done with physical distancing indoors and increase hygiene routines.Finally, by Phase , all pubs will be open as normal - with improved public health advice.

title: unions-criticise-inconclusive-scientific-evidence-behind-school-reopening-plan
story: Teachersrsquo unions are calling on the Government to explain how it is safe for children and staff toto schools in England next month following its publication of scientic evidence.One union leader accused Boris Johnson of taking a ldquocavalier attitude towards children, while another union called evidence from the Governmentrsquos scientic advisers ldquoinconclusive.The remarks come after the Government published documents from the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencieson Friday.Sage looked at the scientic modelling for seven dferent scenarios for school closures, the papers show, but none of the published scenarios looked at the Governmentrsquos plan to reopen schools in England to children in Reception, Year  and Year  from June .One of the documents says the evidence on how likely children are to transmit Covid- remains ldquoinconclusive ndash but the balance of evidence suggests that it may be lower than in adults.Teachers do not appear to be at above average risk compared with other occupations, scientic advisers have suggested, although there is still a chance they can transmit Covid-.The publication of the Sage papers ndash used to inform proposals to reopen schools in England ndash comes after unions, council leaders and MPs demanded to see the scientic evidence underpinning the decision.But following their publication, the school leadersrsquo union NAHT has written to the Education Secretary urging the Government to explain why reopening next month is a ldquowise thing to do.Mary Bousted, joint general secretary of the National Education Union , said: ldquoWe are surprised that the wider opening of schools proposed by Boris Johnson has not been modelled by Sage.ldquoThis points to a cavalier attitude towards the nationrsquos children. The fact of the matter is that Sage has only weak evidence as to what extent children can transmit the virus to others.Dr Bousted added: ldquoIt remains the case that the National Education Union does not yet think it safe for the wider opening of schools.vw,vw,px, px"The children of key workers comply with social distancing rules while attending a hub school in Edinburgh Patrick Roach, general secretary of the NASUWT, added: ldquoThe evidence presented by Sage in terms of justying the decision by Government to start to reopen schools from June  is inconclusive.He added that the Sage papers will ldquoonly add to teachersrsquo uncertainty and anxiety.ldquoThe NASUWT remains of the view that no school should reopen until it can be demonstrated that it is safe to do so, Dr Roach said.It comes after a survey from Unison suggests only % of school support staff felt reassured by the Governmentrsquos recent messaging that schools in England will be safe to reopen from next month.Wider contextual issues ndash including whether families have black, Asian and minority ethnicmembers ndash should be taken into account when assessing the impact of relaxing school closures on transmission, the advice from Sage suggests.It adds that having dferent groups of children attend on alternate weeks may be a good way to ldquostop extensive transmission chains in schools.The documents from Sage suggest that younger teachersrsquo attendance in schools could be prioritised in order to decrease the likelihood of infection for school staff in more vulnerable groups.But reporters were told during a briefing that Office for National Statisticsdata suggests teachers are not at an ldquounusual increase in risk of transmission among than in other professions.Sources involved said the risk of pupils going back to school and becoming seriously ill with Covid- was ldquovery, very, very small but itrsquos ldquonot zero.They said: ldquoThat remains true for every activity outside the house where you might come into contact with people. So itrsquos totally impossible to say that any change has no risk at all.It comes as a separate scientic review of global studies, led by University College London , has suggested that children and young people could be half as likely to catch coronavirus than adults.Researchers found those aged under  had % lower odds of catching Sars-CoV-, the official name of the coronavirus which causes the disease Covid-, from an infected person.With just  days to go until schools could reopen more widely, ministers have come under pressure to reconsider their plans to send more children back to primary school next month.Paul Whiteman, general secretary of the NAHT, said: ldquoSupport for a fixed date for schoolis vanishing quickly. What is needed now is local flexibility to determine when it is right for schools to open up to more pupils, informed by evidence of what is happening in their own local area.Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said: ldquoIt will quickly become clear to anybody reading the papers that the science is not definitive.He added: ldquoThe Government must be able to show very clearly that its five tests have been met before it gives the green light to any wider opening from June , and it must then be flexible about the timescale and approaches needed to bring in eligible pupils.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said: ldquoThe papers published by Sage today show that the phased, cautiousof a limited number of pupils to classrooms has been a carefully considered decision based on the best scientic and medical advice.ldquoMy department continues to engage with the school, college and nursery sectors and I am enormously grateful for all the planning and preparation they are doing, alongside local authorities and academy trusts.ldquoThe welfare of children remains at the very heart of everything we are doing because being able to be back in school will benefit not just their education but also their wellbeing..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Unions criticise  uinconclusive u scientic evidence behind school reopening plan

title: party-people-borders-invited-zoom-disco
story: BORDERERS desperate for a party after spending weeks in lockdown are being invited to throw on their gladrags and dancing shoes ndash and hit the living room for a night in.Mental health campaigner Emma Smith, of Peebles, is organising a virtual disco through Zoom.She said: ldquoI wanted to offer something that people could do from the comfort of their own homes, bringing the community together and giving them a welcome distraction from everything thatrsquos going on right now.Emma already has two successful charity events under her belt, having arranged for local singer-songwriter Tommy Ashby to headline gigs. A total of pound, went to the Scottish Association for Mental Health .Now, however, Emma is inviting people from Tweeddale and beyond to join a virtual dance party.She has teamed up with Silent Adventures to schedule an event for May  called lsquoThe Sessions in aid of SAMH disco In-Furloughrsquo.ldquoAlthough this is something we hadnrsquot planned for initially, the virtual format means we can bring even more people together, so I guess every cloud has a silver lining, said Emma."No matter where peoplersquos loved ones are in the world, or who they are isolating with, as long as they have Zoom they can get involved.Mental health is a cause which is ldquoreally close to Emmarsquos heart, she said, adding: ldquoMy hope is that by raising awareness through our events, and trying to get the message out there that it is OK not to be OK, it will help take the stigma away from something that affects so many people every single day.To take part in the event, which sees profits going to SAMH, Emma says you must register by sending an email to thesessions@hotmail

title: watch-council-meeting-living-room
story: BORDERS residents can tune into a live council meeting on the internet next week.Scottish Borders Councilis hosting a meeting of its Local Review Body on Mondayusing video-conferencing technology.It will be the second meeting organised over Microsoft Teams ndash but the first open to the public.Members of the public will not be allowed to ask questions, however, just as would be the case in physical meetings.The council says the Local Review Body meeting on June  will also be available to the public.The Local Review Body hears appeals against planning permission rejections.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: ldquoThis is an important next step in the council being able to take decisions with absolute transparency while continuing to adhere to guidance on public meetings and social distancing.ldquoWe will continue to review how these initial online meetings operate prior to confirmation of a calendar for future council meetings involving greater numbers of councillors, council officers and agenda items.To access the councils online meetings, you can visit this website.

title: testing-arrivals-airports-not-predictive-says-chief-scientific-adviser
story: Testing visitors to Britain for coronavirus would not circumvent the fresh requirement for them to quarantine for  days after their arrival, the chief scientic adviser has suggested.Home Secretary Priti Patel announced on Friday that self-isolation periods of two weeks will be imposed on new arrivals to the UK from June , with fines for anyone who breaches the measure designed to prevent new waves of coronavirus from overseas.Speaking at the daily Downing Street briefing on Covid-, Sir Patrick Vallance, the UK Governmentrsquos chief scientic adviser, said test results were not conclusive enough to catch every case of coronavirus.He explained that the swab tests being used were not able to decipher whether someone was in the early stages of having contracted coronavirus, a period when those carrying the virus are likely to be asymptomatic.ldquoThe reason a negative test is not very predictive isyoursquove just caught the disease, you incubate it for a few days when you will test negative, he said.ldquoYou start to test positive maybe at around five days, maybe a bit sooner, and you may be shedding a lot of virus for a couple of days then and for a few days afterwards.ldquoAnd then you gradually recover and you may not shed.ldquoSo, clearly, it depends on the time at which you caught the infection as to when you expect a positive test.ldquoThat means just testing somebody and saying, lsquoYoursquore negativersquo, doesnrsquot tell yousomebody is about to get it in a weekrsquos time.Advice published by the Home Office said that ldquofor the moment, testing at the border is not a part of the protection measures.Answering why Britain was not introducing temperature screening at the border like other countries had, the Home Office added: ldquoTemperature testing will not identy everyone who is infected with coronavirus when they enter the UK ndash especially people who have not yet developed symptoms or for who raised temperature is not a symptom.ldquoThat is why we will be asking all travellers to self-isolate for  days.Paul Lincoln, director general of the Border Force, warned prospective travellers that they could be putting lives at riskthey decide to travel with symptoms associated with the deadly disease.ldquoThe advice is quite clear, he said at the press briefing.ldquoIf you have the virus or are displaying the symptoms, oryoursquove been in contact with someone with the virus, you should not travel.ldquoTo do so otherwise is potentially putting peoplersquos lives at risk.Ms Patel reiterated that Government advice continues to be that all but essential foreign travel should be avoided..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Testing arrivals at airports not very predictive, says chief scientic adviser

title: veteran-musicians-mark-ve-day-doorsteps
story: Alastair Knowles BEM played the lsquoLast Postrsquo on the bugle from the front door of his Stoneyhill home and pipe major Stewart Braby performed lsquoBattlersquos Orsquoerrsquo at the Mall near his house in Inveresk Road last Friday.Mr Knowles said he was asked by Iain Clark, from Musselburgh, a Depute Lieutenant of East Lothian, to mark the end of the two -minute silence at am that day by ringing the bell at Northesk Church in Musselburgh, which he duly did.Mr Knowles also heard from Bruno Peek, VE Day  Pageant Master, who was keen to keep as much of the national programme going as possible amidst the coronavirus pandemic.The events were arranged to mark the th anniversary of Victory in Europe Day ndash the day celebrating the formal acceptance by the Allies of the Nazisrsquo unconditional surrender of their armed forces, on Tuesday,  May , marking the end of the Second World War in Europe.Buglers and trumpeters were still urged to sound the lsquoLast Postrsquo, as planned, at .pm, and pipers to play lsquoBattlersquos Orsquoerrsquo at pm.Mr Knowles followed his uncle into the Boysrsquo Brigade in the mid-s.Since then he has become a key part of the group, becoming a bugler and leading drummer in the Penicuik and Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band.He was Town Champion at the  Riding of the Marches in Musselburgh, before being appointed chairman of the  event.He is also a former president of the Old Musselburgh Club.He received the BEM for services to the community in Musselburgh.Mr Braby, pipe major with the Penicuik  Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band, is also pipe major of the massed bands at the Boysrsquo Brigade Beating Retreat at Edinburgh Castle.Mr Knowles said: ldquoLater in the evening my we Lily and I, as our daily exercise outing, took a walk to Northesk, where the third member of the church,Lorraine McBrearty, added her contribution with the singing of lsquoWersquoll Meet Againrsquo only yards from her home on Bridge Street at pm.He added: ldquoIt was a busy but fulfilling day.

title: tributes-paid-caring-gran
story: Irene Grant spent last Friday saying farewell to her mother Mary Jane Gouldingat a funeral parlour before ing for afternoon tea in the garden of her home on Rope Walk, Prestonpans.She was preparing to spend the day alone but Musselburghrsquos Yarnbombers group ndash famous for their wool-based community art displays ndash had arranged to leave lsquoJock and Jeannie,rsquo a knitted lsquocouplersquo, who were due to have pride of place at a street party at Musselburghrsquos Brunton Hall, outside her home.The public event to celebrate the th anniversary of VE Day was cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic but Irene, who was brought up in Musselburgh, was determined to mark the occasion the way her -year-old mum would have wanted.Irene went to her doorstep at am to observe the nationrsquos twominute silence before she and her neighbours had afternoon tea in their own gardens as well as a social distance singalong featuring an emotional rendition of lsquoWersquoll Meet Again.Irene, a member of the yarnbombers, decorated her garden with knitted cakes, a lsquogrow your own vegetablesrsquo display and put up bunting ndash in keeping with the grouprsquos tradition of brightening up Musselburgh with dferent knitted displays since the Riding of the Marches in .A founder member of Musselburghrsquos Clark Concert Party, she said: ldquoI was at the undertaker making arrangements for mum and came home to Jock and Jeannie sitting on my steps. It was an amazing surprise ndash although I got the fright of my le. You have no idea how much it cheered me up and gave me a much needed laugh. My friends in the Yarnbombers decided I needed company. I was determined to go ahead with a wee party, although I live on my own and have no one to celebrate with. Mum was in a nursing home and the family had not seen her for eight weeks nor were we permitted to be with her at the end.Mary, who was resident at Drummond Grange Nursing Home at Lasswade, took a ldquosevere decline two weeks before her death.Irene said: ldquoShe was not eating or drinking. Everyone thought she had lsquoturned her back to the wallrsquo with being in isolation. Her attending doctor thought she would test her for Covid and we got the news that it was positive. Mum had shown no symptoms whatsoever. She died on Sunday, May .Mary was born in Nova Scotia, Canada, in March , where her parents George and Mary Grahamhad emigrated to after her father was laid off during the General Strike of .They ed to Prestonpans four years later and Mary, her two sisters and three brothers, enjoyed ldquoan extremely happy childhood at their home in Nethershot.Her dad was a miner at Prestongrange colliery all his working le.Mary married her husband Jim Goulding on March , , at Newcraighall Church, and Irene and her sister Janice had a happy childhood growing up at Galt Crescent in Musselburgh.Mary worked as a carer home help until her retirement.After she and Jim orced, she moved to South Street where she lived for a few years before moving to amenity housing on Hercus Loan.She was diagnosed with vascular dementia in  and, in , went into care, latterly becoming a resident at Drummond Grange.Irene said: ldquoThis became her home and our family will never be able to thank the staff there enough for the love and care they showed her, particularly in these past weeks. One observation about the staff came from the undertaker who said lsquothey had dressed your mum in her Sunday best and she looked gorgeousrsquo.She added: ldquoWe cannot be sad that mum has gone because of the torment her mind was in for so long but we are all devastated with the circumstances in which she went ndash not seeing any of us for so long. For the first time in any of our lives, we missed being with her on her birthday and on Motherrsquos Day. It is such a tragic way to end a long fruitful le. She was so caring to everyone and had a wicked sense of humour which transcended the generations.A spokesperson for the nursing home said: ldquoWe would like to extend our deepest condolences to the family and friends who have lost a loved one in this awful pandemic. Mary was a much loved member of the community who treated everyone with kindness and respect, and will be dearly missed.Mary had bequeathed her body to medical science but this cannot happen in the current circumstances, so her funeral took place at Seafield Crematorium on Wednesday, which was attended by her immediate family.She is survived by her daughters Irene and Janice, four grandchildren, her sisters Isobel and Georgie, and many friends particularly Faye and Rod Gibson.The family have set up The Mary Goulding Celebration Fund to raise money for Alzheimer Scotland.To donate go to https:marygoulding.muchloved

title: covid-19-testing-centre-opening-former-power-station-site
story: The drive-through centre will be operated by the st Infantry Brigade which oversees the army reserve unitsin Scotland and will carry out tests on key workers from tomorrowto Monday with plans toagain in two weeksrsquo time.East Lothian Council confirmed it had made the site available as part of the UKGovernmentrsquos Covid- testing programme.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre since the start of April.The Cockenzie site, bought by the local authority from ScottishPower, is currently being marketed for economic investment.In preparation of the appointment-only testing unitrsquos opening, signs and cones have been put in place to direct drivers.The centre will re-open on Saturday, May , through to Monday, June , and is providing back-up support to a main testing centre at EdinburghAirport.Key workers who have symptoms, or have a member of their household displaying symptoms, can self-refer to the site through the UK Governmentrsquos online portal.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site while the facility is closed.The council said it expects the unit to operate as a self-contained, drivethrough facility.People will remain in their vehicle while being tested.It is not known how many tests can be carried out at the site each day.Tom Reid, the councilrsquos head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel.ldquoThis facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-. East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the move to open the centre at Cockenzie.He said: ldquoI have been calling on the Scottish Government to follow the World Health Organisationrsquos advice and ramp up the amount of testing we are doing for over a month now, so I welcome this new centre in Cockenzie and hope it will mean local key workers do not have to travel so far to access a test.ldquoA signicant increase in testing capacity will be essentialthe Scottish Governmentrsquos plans for testing, tracing and isolating are to be successful and this centre will contribute to the expansion needed.The move was also welcomed by local community councils.Bryan Hickman, chairperson of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, said: ldquoWe are pleased that the site is being used for a testing unit. It seems very suitable and hopefully it will help in getting this terrible virus under control.Brian Weddell, chairperson of Prestonpans Community Council, said: ldquoThe former power station site at Preston Links is an ideal location for a Covid testing site for East Lothian. It is remote enough from local communities with plenty of space to ensure government distancing regulations are maintained.The drive-through testing centres are available to people who live less than  minutes drive from them and are in addition to NHS Scotland testing.Scottish Government guidelines on who can apply for a test at the UK Government mobile testing centres are on their website.For a full list of those eligible to go bit.ly csBii Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via the self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stationrsquos famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September , two years after it had closed.

title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: blow-musselburgh-racing-hopes
story: Bosses at the East Lothian track had hoped to hold races behind closed doors on Saturday, June , as the industry looks to restart under restrictions.Groundstaff at thetownrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, were expected to temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.And East Lothian MP Kenny Macaskill added his voice to a letter to Scottish sports minister Joe FitzPatrick, MSP, urging him to allow Scotlands racecourse to host fixtures as soon as possible.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, was due on Monday to bring a report to MRACwhich oversees course governance, setting out hopes of a restart in early June.However, the BHA released its provisional fixture list for the restart yesterdayand all the racing proposed is in England.The BHA said thatGovernment restrictions eased at the end of the month, it intended to start behind-closed-door racing at Newcastle on June  with  meetings at seven tracks planned for the first eight days of racing.After a single meeting on June  there will be at least two meetings each day with three ndash one each in the north, south and midlands ndash scheduled from Saturday June  to Monday June  inclusive.There will be no regional restrictions on runners competing at any meetings.Mr Farnsworth had hoped Musselburgh would be allowed to take part in the behind closed doors fixtures in June after pointing out how the industry was ready to go.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday,June  butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds itself in a unique position compared to other Scottish sports in that our equine athletes, cherished so highly by those in the industry, have remained in training during thepandemic and will therefore be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: new-town-top-low-carbon-location
story: The local authority has lodged its vision for the future with Scottish Ministers as they prepare to create a new National Policy Framework .But it has warned its ambitions must not be sacriced in a rush to kickstart the economy as the nation comes out of lockdown.In an opening statement to their submission, officials expressed concern that new developments may lose sight of the long-term ambition they have for the county.They tell the Scottish Government: ldquoThe current challenges brought about by coronavirus may have lasting effects on the economy.ldquoWhile demand for new development will , it is important that, in the short term, standards in new development are not prejudiced to stimulate growth.ldquoThe ambitions around climate change, ecology, health and well-being, equality, connectivity, inclusive growth and place-making remain.East Lothian Council wants the National Development designation given to the former Cockenzie Power Station site in previous frameworks to be expanded to include the new town of Blindwells which is underway on nearby land, in the new NPF.The council believes that National Development status for the wider area including nearby Blindwells would support ambitions for sustainable growth and an emerging vision for the area to be an influential, innovative, healthy and carbon neutral location.And they say the larger site could become one of Scotlands top ten low carbon locations.While the boundaries of the area are still to be finalised it could stretch out to cover existing communities of Tranent, Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry.Councillor Norman Hampshire, East Lothian Council spokesperson for Environment, said it was important the county continued to plan for the future during the Covid- outbreak.And he said it was important the ambitions set out before the lockdown continued to be at the heart of decisions made.He said: ldquoWe are ambitious for East Lothian and want to see it remain as a great place in which to live and work, which is well connected with good employment opportunities and sustainability principles at its heart.The local authority has asked Scottish Ministers to designate an area known as The Blindwells, Cockenzie and Climate Change Zone, as a National Development.Councillor Hampshire said: ldquoWe want to see the new settlement at Blindwells developed as a fantastic community in which to live and work.ldquoIt should be a zero emissions community embracing climate change objectives and embracing blue green infrastructure and bioersity.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site offers signicant opportunity in terms of economic development and employment and work continues to understand its potential.ldquoIn our proposal for a National Development, we are suggesting that a Climate Change Zone is created between these sites, and including parts of, neighbouring communities and sites.ldquoWe believe this wider area, part of the former East Lothian coalfield, could be one of Scotlandrsquos top  locations for low carbon, sustainable inclusive growth and we are determined to grasp the opportunity.ldquoWe are making our case in a submission to the Scottish Government and will be carrying out public engagement on the extent of our vision for the area in due course.

title: edf-donates-3-000-face-masks-crossreach
story: CrossReach, which provides social care services on behalf of the Church of Scotland, has received , face masks from EDF Energy, operators of Torness Power Station.The masks will be used to ensure that staff and residents are protected during the Covid- outbreak.Torness Power Station, near Dunbar, along with its sister station in North Ayrshire and EDFrsquos office in East Kilbride, have each given , masks.CrossReach previously had a facility on Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Road, before it moved to Aldhammer House, Prestonpans.Elspeth McPheat, one of CrossReachrsquos care home managers, said: ldquoIt is amazing how kind and thoughtful people are being.ldquoIt means so much to know that, as social care workers, you are loved and cared for by others when you are loving and caring for those in your care.Rob Guyler, EDFrsquos chief financial officer, said: ldquoWe want to be able to do our bit to support people in the community during these dficult times so we are happy to make this donation.

title: outstanding-response-resilience-groups-noted-holyrood
story: Hundreds of kind-hearted volunteers from across the county have stepped forward to help vulnerable members of society during the coronavirus crisis.Volunteers in every town and village have done everything from providing hot meals and walking dogs to collecting shopping and prescriptions.Those efforts were recognised by the countyrsquos MSP, Iain Gray, who tabled a motion at the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh.He said: ldquoFrom the outset of this crisis, the response from every community across East Lothian has been absolutely outstanding.ldquoLocal people have demonstrated great community spirit and compassion for their neighbours, with thousands becoming involved in local resilience groups and other community support activity. Everyone involved. . . has come together to protect and support the vulnerable, especially those in the shielding group, through this most dficult of times. This community togetherness will come as no surprise to local people, who know that we look after one another here.The motion thanks community groups and calls on the Scottish Parliament to recognise and commend the outstanding response to the Covid- pandemic by resilience groups and volunteers across East Lothian notes that over , volunteers have become involved in community support activity via these groups, helping to organise and carry out a wide range of tasks to inform, advise and assist residents, especially people who are shielding or self-isolating acknowledges the important work undertaken by staff at East Lothian Council, especially its local area partnerships, community councils, community and residentsrsquo associations and groups, charities and voluntary groups and businesses to help establish, co-ordinate and support the resilience effort to ensure that the most vulnerable in the community have the support that they need during the crisis, and thanks everyone involved in this activity for their contribution to community resilience and cohesion across the county during this unprecedented time.

title: charity-delivers-art-packs-vulnerable-residents
story: Stepping Out, which is based in the townrsquos community centre but covers the whole of East Lothian, is creating and delivering art bags to those who use its service and usually attend its art class on a Monday.The bags each contain items unique to the inidual, and have been put together by art teacher Liz Walker.Project manager Nicky Fox said the charity did consider hosting the class on Zoom, but realised this would not be suitable for certain people and for those without access to the necessary technology .The classes were instead moved to WhatsApp, a more accessible  which allows for interaction.Nicky said: ldquoWhat Liz started to do was, every day, post a picture of something she had painted or done herself.ldquoShersquod then ask them to do something like that, or nothing, or whatever they fancy.ldquoWersquore keeping in touch with those that use our service every day rather than once a week.Nicky added that Stepping Out was also starting a lsquophoto a dayrsquo initiative with the art group, in the hope of encouraging more involvement.She said: ldquoThe response when we managed to deliver the bags was amazing. A lot of people are quite isolated, which is part of the reason for doing it. They were so happy to get the bag of stuff, itrsquos like a present for them.ldquoOne lady was so excited she sent pictures of each inidual item.ldquoNorth Berwick Community Centre have also been very helpful, both to us and the town as a whole, and have been giving some people extra meals.Some of those in the charityrsquos healthy minds happy babies group have also received art supplies.Nicky also thanked the local playgroup who donated some toys and supplies to make playdough.Meanwhile, another one of the charityrsquos groups has been adding songs to a playlist to keep them in touch and entertained during lockdown. Nicky added thatanyone would like to donate art supplies or help the charity in any way they could get in touch with Stepping Out on Facebook ndash www.facebook Steppingouteastlothian

title: talented-dancer-joins-sister-city-ballet-school
story: Kitty Rose Black, , joins sister Maisie, , at Edinburgh Festival Ballet after successfully auditioning earlier this year.The school is run by Danish ballet dancer and artistic director and principal of English National Ballet, Peter Schaufuss.Kitty, Maisie and mum Pauline are spending lockdown in Corstorphine in Edinburgh but are permanently moving back to Westerdunes Park, North Berwick, next month.Kitty, a former Dirleton Primary School pupil, is due to start in August and is ldquoreally excited at the prospect of joining a talented group of dancers.She said: ldquoI have been told by Maisie that it is really fun. I like to be challenged. I actually canrsquot wait.ldquoAll of the part-time students go together in one class so I will be with my sister in some classes.Kitty, who started dancing at the age of four and used to train with Dunbar School of Dance, currently trains with Velasco Walker School of Dance and Scottish Ballet junior associates.She was  years old at the time of her audition, which was completed amongst students who were older than her and auditioning for full-time places at the school, something she called ldquoquite challenging.The audition process consisted of a filmed two-hour dance class.She was inspired to audition and join the school after attending an open day and watching some of the dancers, one of whom was her sister, perform.Due to coronavirus, both Kitty and Maisie have been training through Zoom to ensure they do not lose their skills.Kitty said: ldquoWhen Maisie first did a Zoom lesson I watched her and was so keen to do it. Maisie has really come on this past year so hopefully it will strengthen me, too.On her love of dance, Kitty said: ldquoI love dancing. I go to school then come back and do dancing.ldquoI feel free doing it, like nothing can stop me. I donrsquot think about anything , I just love dancing. I want to be a ballet dancer when Irsquom older, thatrsquos my dream right now.Kitty is also due to start secondary school and has been accepted by both The Dance School of Scotland in Glasgow and Erskine Stewartrsquos Melville School in Edinburgh.She is yet to decide which one to attend.

title: praise-music-teachers-noteworthy-contribution
story: Nicola Presavage, from Haddington, an instrumental co-ordinator in music percussion at Loretto School, Musselburgh, is on furlough leave.For the past three weeks, she has been making face masks and headbands, free of charge, for nurses, care home workers, shop assistants, cleaners and even an offshore medic!The headbands are for people who find wearing face masks on their ears uncomfortable, with more than  already distributed.They work by looping the elastic or ties from masks around the button of the headband instead of around the ears. The buttons are in a position just behind the ear.Mrs Presavage has also issued  washable cloth-made face masks to recipients.Most of the masks and headbands have been collected from her house and, in keeping with social distancing, she has clipped them to her fence in sealed bags for people to collect. She has also posted out some orders.Many people in the community have been supporting the initiative by dropping off spare fabric or buttons they had at home.Mrs Presavage said: ldquoHearing tales from key workers dealing with all of this from the frontline is quite harrowing and puts everything into perspective.She added: ldquoI originally put a post on Facebook and asked for anyone looking for one to get in touch. As long as I am on furlough I am happy to keep making them. Elastic is becoming more dficult to source though.Her initiative has taken off, so she is now requesting pound. per mask to cover the cost of materials after running out of her original supply of fabric.She isnrsquot taking any more orders at the moment due to a backlog but is hoping to do so again soon.A Loretto School spokesperson added: ldquoHer contribution to helping those on the frontline is amazing ndash wersquore so proud.Mrs Presavage can be contacted via the Haddington Community Council Facebook page.

title: learning-late-19th-century-dunbar
story: The group was due to hold its annual general meeting last month. The meeting, which was postponed, is usually preceded by short talks by committee members and instead took place as a virtual gathering.Dr Jim Herring, who looks after the societyrsquos website, put together a presentation entitled The  Map of Dunbar: An Illustrated Talk.The video was then posted to the grouprsquos website and on YouTube.The talk begins with an explanation of the names of the rocks which can be seen off Winterfield Promenade ndash the West Promenade on the map ndash and Dunbar Harbour, such as Wallacersquos Head, Scart Rock, The Yetts and The Gripes.Dr Herring said: ldquoI had no idea what the names meant, so got help from two experts on Scottish place names and found out the most likely explanations.The talk then looked at some new buildings in Dunbar which were not included in an  map, including The Old Ship Inn, The Hotel Bellevue and the Roxburghe Hotel, originally known as The Roxburghe Marine Hotel.Dr Herring added: ldquoI found some really interesting information. For example, the Bellevue Hotel was designed around the calendar, with four floors,  public rooms,  bedrooms, etc.The virtual talk, is available via the History Society website at dunbarhistory.org.uk

title: schoolboys-bounce-way-1-500-target
story: Jamie Heggie and Blake Urquhart, of Pencaitland, were among thousands across the country taking part in The . Challenge.The organisers of the London Marathon, which was postponed due to the coronavirus outbreak, encouraged people to take on their own challenge involving the numbers two and six.And while others have been walking, cycling and jogging, the two Pencaitland Primary School pupils used their pogo sticks to raise money for St Columbarsquos Hospice Care.Jamiersquos dad, Jon, who is director of fundraising at the charity, was pleased to say both of the youngsters completed , bounces.He told the Courier it was almost more dficult to count the bounces than to take on the challenge!He said: ldquoJamie and Blake were challenging each other to do  bounces, then the other had to do  bounces and then  just to keep themselves amused.ldquoWe said, lsquoCould you do , each in a day rsquo and they both got really excited.ldquoIt took off from there.ldquoIt only took them half an hour ndash they thought they were going to have to have loads of breaks!The charity, which has a shop on Haddington High Street, provides hospice and end-of-le care for people with incurable illnesses and their families, in Edinburgh and across the Lothians.Jon said a number of charities had been impacted by the coronavirus outbreak, which had seen fundraisers of all sizes postponed or cancelled.However, friends and family had got behind Jamie and Blake, both seven, with an initial fundraising target well and truly smashed.Jon added: ldquoFriends and family have been so generous. We had a target of pound to tie in with the . challenge and thought they would be overwhelmedthey got that.ldquoThey are now over pound, itrsquos pretty incredible.To make a donation, go to www.stcolumbashospice.org.uk or call   .

title: tributes-paid-british-legion-loses-two-members
story: Chairman of the branch Edward OrsquoConnor died on May , at Tranent Care Home, where he was being cared for after suffering a minor stroke.Mr OrsquoConnor, , was described by branch secretary Andrew Davie as an active member who was always involved in ious s in the club, often officiating in sports and competitions such as golf, bowling, fishing, dominoes and darts.Mr Davie said Mr OrsquoConnor had also been the first to join a recently created area of the British Legion, Edinburgh, Lothians and Borders. He carried out his duties as chairman all over Scotland representing the new area.Mr Davie said: ldquoHe will be missed by all the members, as he was always in the club. His long service in the RAF, home and abroad will be remembered.Mr OrsquoConnor leaves one daughter, Sharon.The branch also lost management committee member Alistair Marshall in March.Mr Marshall was well known for collecting thousands of pounds for Poppyscotland and acting as standard bearer for the Royal British Legionat ceremonial events.Mr Marshall, who was , served in the Royal Engineers.Mr Davie said: ldquoAlistair was involved in doing many things when on the committee. As a dedicated doorman at the weekend he made sure everybody behaved themselves. At other events he was a collector for Poppyscotland, especially during Armistice Remembrance, raising many thousands of pounds.ldquoHe was also a standard bearer, carrying out his duties at ceremonial events for RBL and at the passing away of our many comrades, at the graveside and crematoriums.ldquoTo his we Sylvia and stepchildren Karen and Bob, we send our deepest sympathy. He will be sadly missed by all his comrades.

title: column-recognising-key-workers
story: Many of these are frankly ridiculous, but presumably someone makes a living from sending out press releases to parliamentarians asking them to mark National Chip Dayor the like.The parliamentary equivalent is the parliamentary motion.MSPs can put these down to recognise important local achievements, they are published in the daily business bulletin, and other MSPs add their name in support.Some of them,they achieve cross party support, will be debated in parliament.Like national lsquodaysrsquo these motions can be devalued by overuse ndash which some of my colleagues are guilty of ndash but I do use them to give credit where credit is due.In these times of crisis, giving credit where itrsquos due has never been more important.Recent weeks have seen International Nursesrsquo Day, Firefightersrsquo Memorial Day, Postal Workersrsquo Day and Bus  Coach Worker Support Day.I have taken care to acknowledge and mark each one of those, on social media, and in signing parliamentary motions supporting them.Of course, every Thursday is NHS and Care Workersrsquo Day, when the country says thank you on our doorsteps.But these other national days remind us that a wide range of workers from bus drivers to bin collectors, to teachers in the school lsquohubsrsquo are risking their own health to keep things going.None more so, of course, than supermarket and other shop staff, which is why I am supporting my colleague Daniel Johnsonrsquos Memberrsquos Bill to protect shop workers from abuse at work.If these key workers do have something in common, it is that they are mostly unappreciated and poorly paid in normal times. Now that we see how vital their work is to us, there is really no excuse for letting that injustice persist, hence the growing campaign, which I back, to see key workers receive a pound per hour pay increase.To see these workers valued properly would be a positive legacy of this dreadful crisis.

title: pretty-puffin-posters-proposed-please-passers
story: Mairi McGinley said the idea came up in a discussion with fellow members of the North Berwick Community Resilience Group.ldquoWe were trying to come up with some way of bringing the community together from a distance, she said.ldquoWe knew lots of children had been enjoying spotting rainbow pictures and teddy bears in windows whilst on their daily walks, so we thought why not do something a bit more lsquoNorth Berwickrsquo and give the childrena new art project to work on.ldquoMy daughter in P had been given a puffin picture project by her teacher Alan Connell for their art class, so we knew it was something a lot of the children would be doing already.ldquoThe idea is the same as that of the rainbow pictures ndash create some puffin themed art work to display in your window.ldquoIf puffins are tricky, then something beach-themed would be fab andyoursquore not keen on art projects, then you could display a puffin toy, tea towel or poster.Puffins are particularly associated with the island of Craigleith off the shore of North Berwick.It was once one of Britainrsquos biggest colonies of puffins, with , pairs in , but numbers have fallen dramatically in recent years due to the invasion of tree mallow, which chokes up the puffin burrows.

title: fundraiser-memory-life-soul-party-ben
story: Ben Forsyth passed away in July,  after being forced to give up the sport he loved in , following a diagnosis of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathyndash a progressive and incurable disease of the heart muscles.His friend Katie Murray, a -year-old nurse, is hoping to raise funds through a challenge which encourages people to participate in health and fitness activities during May, June and July.This month people are being urged to walk  miles which is roughly .km a day or , steps.In the month of June, , squats shouldbe undertaken, with , burpeescompleted in July.Money raised will go to Cardiac Risk in the Young , which offers cardiac screening to young people, in memory of Ben who passed away after a sudden cardiac event.Following a cardiac screening in , an irregularity was discovered in his heart which led to him being referred to the NHS.In May , he started to develop breathing problems during races and a further MRI scan revealed he had ARVC.A former Musselburgh Grammar School pupil and member of Edinburgh Road Clubcycling club, he won the British Youth Circuit Race Championship in  at Blackpool.A member of Spokes race team, he also raced with Olympic cyclinglegend Sir Chris Hoy at the opening the Sir Chris Hoy Velodrome in Glasgow.Katie, who works in the Department of Clinical Neurosciences at the Western General Hospital in Edinburgh, hopes the fitness challenge will bring some fun to lockdown and encourage people to get moving and join in with their friends and family.She said: ldquoI think this will help keep people motivated to keep active during lockdown as it gives us all a goal to work towards whilst raising money for a brilliant cause.ldquoCRY is a fantastic charity that offers cardiac screening to all young people between the ages of  and , and helps to detect cardiac abnormalities in people within this age group. So far, CRY have been able to screen , young people across the UK. Thanks to fundraising efforts from Benrsquos family and friends, this is a number that we hope will continue to rise.Katie, who knew Ben since P at Stoneyhill Primary School, added: ldquoFor every month successfully completed, we ask for a donation of pound. If not completed then we would appreciate any donation at all.Mutual friends are getting involved to complete the challenge and Katie added: ldquoSome are making adjustments to the challenges so that they are able to participate and complete the challenge in a way that enables them to do so, and I would strongly recommend this for anyone who wishes to take part and join us.Katie, of Denholm Road, and Ben, whose family live in the Clayknowes area, both went to Musselburgh Grammar School and lived one street apart.She said: ldquoWe were close friends both in and out of school and shared lots of mutual friends. Following school, we both went to Edinburgh University where Ben studied geography and I studied nursing. Although we both studied dferent courses, I still saw Ben on a regular basis as our group of school friends has remained close.ldquoHe was always the le and soul of the party and had an infectious energy that followed him everywhere he went. A great person to be around and an even better friend, so kind and generous. Even when he was living le to the full, he always had time for other people, be it his friends or family.To donate, go to Virgin Money Giving at https:uk.virginmoneygiving KatieMurray

title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-restrictions-eased-may-28---know
story: The First Minister today revealed that the Scottish Government will publish a route map for the paths out of lockdown.She said thatprogress is being made in reducing the spread of the virus, changes could be made after the next review date of May .This would come after taking into account the reproduction rateof the virus, alongside the findings of the weekly National Records of Scotlandreport.Ms Sturgeon said changes could include some sporting events being allowed, including golf and fishing, as well as the opening of garden centres.Other potential easings includeletting people meet those from other households, provided social distancing is followed.The First Minister also said that more will be said about when schools might reopen.The First Minister said at the briefing: ldquoWithin two weeks, my hope is that we will be taking some concrete steps on the journey back to normality.ldquoAs Irsquove said before, it wonrsquot be normality as we knew it because the virus will not have gone away, but it will be a journey to a better balance ndash I hope ndash than the one we have today.ldquoAs we take each step, we must make sure that the ground beneath us is as solid as possible.ldquoThatrsquos why sticking with the lockdown restrictions a bit longer to suppress the virus more is so important, because that will mean we can start to take these steps with the confidence that we have alternative means of effectively keeping it under control.The First Minister said for the moment there is no change to the lockdown advice currently being circulated by the Scottish Government.

title: new-racecourse-operators-getting-ready-take-reins
story: Delays to finalising a deal between East Lothian Council and Chester Race Company meant that the planned handover at the end of March this year did not go ahead.However during an online meeting today of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee , which currently oversees the governance of the course, members were told Chester will take over "no later than" June .Reading a joint statement on behalf of the council and Chester, the local authoritys legal adviser Carlo Grilli said talks between the two parties continued positively.He said: "We continue to work positively with Chester and both parties are working on details of the contract to allow a transfer date of no later than  June."Mr Grilli declined to discuss details of the contract during the public part of the meeting which was held via Skype after he was quizzed about prize money and priority races commitments agreed between the council and Chester.The racecourse was managed until  by Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee, which was made up of three elected East Lothian councillors and two members of Lothians Racing Syndicate.However, after an independent review called into question the governance of that committee amid claims of toxic relationships between members, the council replaced it with MRAC,which has four councillors and two racing experts on it, and agreed to find a third-party operator to take over its management.Chester was announced as the preferred operator in October last year and discussions over the details of the -year lease have been ongoing.Delays to the initialy March handover were put down to the coronavirus crisis.Councillor Stuart Currie, MRAC member, welcomed news that a June deadline is being worked towards.He said: "I think I speak on behalf of everyone when I sayI am really pleased we seem to be moving towards a conclusion."

title: scotlands-schools-set-return-august-11-part-time-phased-re-opening
story: The proposals would mean some teachers wouldto work in June in preparation, with childrens "blended" learning involving spending half their time in the classroom, and half at home.The Daily Record revealed the plans reportedly put together by Education Secretary John Swinney.It comes after Boris Johnson revelaed plans to reopenschools for some pupils in England by June .Some pupils starting primary and secondary, according to the paper, will be allowed to access schools next month."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Scotlands plan to ease lockdown on May ","description": "Nicola Sturgeon outlines route map to ease lockdown on May ","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media cLhsyfqt poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests cLhsyfqt.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.eastlothiancourier video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "East Lothian Courier","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.eastlothiancourier sitelogo ","width": ,"height": One senior education source told the Recordsaid: ldquoTrying to reopen schools in a pandemic was always going to be a big challenge but lots of effort has gone into this plan.ldquoIt is obviously dependent on the science butthe scientic advice is positive then this plan can be implemented and children will be able toto school safely.Its reported that the Education Recovery Groupm chaired by Swinney, has been working on the plan to reopen schools on August .Biut that is dependent on scientic advice, an effective "test, trace and isolate" stategy and enough PPE Stocks for staff.A Scottish Government spokesperson told the RecordldquoThursdayrsquos route-map will also set out our up to date assessment at that point of a phasedto school, as guided by the considerations of the Education Recovery Group.

title: raf-reveals-many-planes-seen-coronavirus-lockdown
story: And out in the countryside, several people have reported hearing jets regualarlyscreaming through the skies late at night.Now the RAF has spoken out to reassure the public that there is nothing sinister taking place and reveal the real reason why its aircraft have been seen across Scotland.The most noticeable planes to have been spotted recently launched from RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire.These large aircraft have been observed circling Glasgow as well as making brief landings during "touch and go" manoeuvres designed to practice these tricky and sometimes risky touchdowns.In wartime, some planes have to make landings on rough terrain, so its imperative that pilots are as well-practised as possible." alt"East Lothian Courier: This is an Airbus AM Atlas, the type of airfact seen over Glasgow in recent weeks " class"editor-image"This is an Airbus AM Atlas, the type of airfact seen over Glasgow in recent weeks A spokesman for RAF Lossiemouth told The Herald:"Due to the lockdown, the public have become more aware and interested in these activities."To be clear, these were all occurring prior to the pandemic. But a lack of civil aviation now makes them stand out more."Many of the larger aircraft based out of RAF Brize Norton, such as the C- Hercules, AM Atlas, A-MRTT Voyager, and C- Globemaster regularly fly on essential, but routine training missions around the United Kingdom."The C- and A in particular fly quite low-level profiles, and on operations they will be used to land in areas where there are not established runway surfaces."This can include landing on beaches, for example."The quiet skies have made it easier to spot military planes, which can sometimes be identied and followed using apps like FlightRadar.Occasionally, the military planes have been observed performing strange-looking manoeuvres such as flying around in circles .The RAF said these odd flight patterns have a clear explanation: the aircraft were involved in mid-air refuelling.For the last three weeks RAF Lossiemouth has been involved in night flying exercise which concluded on Friday, May  involving Typhoon jets."During our night flying window, we launched our first set of sorties around ," the spokesman added."This meant we were able to generate two or three training serials a day ndash two in daylight, and one in low-light conditions."The Typhoon is a multi-role aircraft, which means itrsquos able to conduct a number of dferent missions while in the air air-to-air and air-to-ground manoeuvres to name two."To enable our Typhoons to stay on task for longer and travel larger distances, we are often supported by Voyagers ndash the RAFrsquos air-to-air refuelling aircraft based at RAF Brize Norton."These Voyager aircraft will fly lsquoracetracks in the skyrsquo, and are usually visible on flight tracking websites which pick up ADS-B."In the United Kingdom, live-armed Typhoons are on "constant standby to react against unidentied aircraft approaching UK airspace as well as aircraft that are operating in an unusual manner, which may pose a threat".Typhoons are often scrambled on "Quick Reaction Alert" missions to intercept planes which enter British airspace"Our last intercept was against two Bear-F ndash Russian Maritime Patrol Aircraft on April ," the spokesman said."Additionally the Typhoon Force are involved in NATO Air Policing missions, such as Op AZOTIZE in Lithuania where  Squadron deployed a few weeks ago."Typhoons have also been involved in strikes against Daesh."A Typhoon jetIf youre worried by the sudden appearance of a military aeroplane, you can generally find out what its up to by visiting offical Twitter accounts or the RAF website."The RAF has always been open about its operations and exercises," the spokesman continued."With the public now spending more time at home, many have taken to their gardens or spent more time on their phones."They have also become more acutely aware of the noises above their houses, and wersquove seen a signicant increase in interest in routine, but essential flying as a result."When we do launch Quick Reaction Alert, wherever possible we publish information as to who we intercepted, what the aircraft were doing, why the interception was carried out, roughly where it all happened, and we aim to answer as many questions we can whilst maintaining operational security."Itrsquos vital that the public understand why this activity is essential to the defence of the United Kingdom."

title: lockdown-measures-lifted-scotland-may-28
story: She confirmed that a "route map" for paths out of lockdown will be published on Thursday.She said thatprogress is being made in reducing the spread of the virus, changes could be made after the next review date of May .But that would be reliant on continued improvements, taking into account the reproduction rateof the virus, andthe findings of the weekly National Records of Scotlandreport.Until then, the Scottish Government advice remains the same: stay at home.SportsIts no secret that many Scots have been longing toto some outdoor leisure activities.Its thought that officials are considering whether sports like golf, tennis and fishing couldafter the next review.That comes after the limit of exercise Scots were allowed to do each day was extended from once per day at the start of lockdown, to unlimited.Garden centresThis is another area in which Scotland has taken a more relaxed approach from England and Wales.Currently, south of the border, garden centres have reopened, with Tory MSP Rachael Hamilton dubbing the decision not to open them as "completely illogical".Recycling centresThe issue of recycling centres has been a hot topic for many local areas title: nicola-sturgeon-sets-plans-get-people-scotland-back-work-latest-cases-revealed
story: Speaking at the latest coronavirus briefing in Edinburgh, the First Minister announced a pound million boost, admiting the restrictions are creating an ldquoeconomic emergency.She saida rise in in Lothian there are , and in Lanarkshire.In the Borders, there are confirmed cases, with in the Highlands.In Ayrshire and Arran there are  confirmed cases, and  in Tayside.Ms Sturgeons announcement
